Award.AwardTitle: CIF: IHCS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Design and Implementation of Position-Encoded 3D Microarrays

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research involves design and building of a three-dimensional (3D) microarray device, with position-controlled microspheres, to perform simultaneous, efficient, and accurate screening of complementary DNAs, RNAs, and protein receptors on a single platform. This new device is portable, self-contained, automatic, and cost effective. Applications of this device include medical screening, drug discovery, and gene sequencing. In particular, it performs inexpensive disease diagnosis and provide insight into the molecular basis in different patients.

In existing 3D microarrays, microspheres are placed randomly within a substrate. This random placement of the microspheres makes their packing inefficient and their data processing complex. To overcome these drawbacks, the investigators design and build new microarrays with position-controlled microspheres. They analyze the statistical accuracy in estimating the target concentrations by computing performance bounds, and apply the results to select the minimal distance between the microspheres and the best operating temperature, while ensuring desired optimal estimation accuracy. The minimal microsphere distance enables high packing, and the optimal temperature reduces the cost. The investigators implement the position-controlled microarray using a microfluidic approach; particularly, they emplace the microspheres using a hydrodynamic trapping mechanism and using on-chip microvalves and pumps. The long-term goal is to integrate this device with image sensors, electronics, and optofluidic imaging to build a complete lab-on-a-chip system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we developed novel microarrays for detecting and identifying various target compounds. Microarrays typically are used for medical purposes, estimating concentrations and identifying various organic molecules (such as proteins, antibodies, mRNA etc.) in a solution. The microarrays we considered have arrays of spherical, microscopic sensors (5-6 μm in diameter) that are placed within a substrate for this purpose. Most common microarrays are based on two-dimensional color-encoded microspheres that are placed upon a substrate.  Three-dimensional microsphere arrays are more sensitive.  However, existing microsphere arrays are placed randomly; they detect and identify different targets by the color of their microscopic (quantum-dot) indicator and suffer from inaccuracies due to imaging errors. We instead proposed to use position-encoded microarrays in a rigid structure. Their microspheres are rigidly fixed within a predefined structure, with the target for each microsphere dependent upon its position. Thus, the identification of the targets is done accurately based on each microsphere's known position.

We overcame various challenges that appeared in the development of our proposed microsphere array.  We compared the performance of the proposed array against the statistically-optimal performance bounds, such as the Posterior Cramer-Rao Bound and the Ziv-Zakai Bound. We determined the ideal structure for such an array, by mathematically minimizing the expected interference while still retaining as fine a resolution as possible. We addressed challenges in the construction of such an array.  We designed a microfluidic trap array in which an array of microsphere traps is used to fix microspheres in place.  Our microfluidic design allows the accurate placement of microspheres in a specific orientation and density, and enables to have one microsphere only placed in each desired position.

We tested the performance of our newly developed array in realistic settings. We determined that an array constructed in this fashion was capable of detecting individual strands of target DNA. We have performed sensitivity studies based on fluoroimmunoassays for the proposed array. We have shown a detection limit of 12.5 ng/ml for the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in PBS using our newly developed device. This result is comparable to the EGFR detection limit in  the state-of-the-art methods. We also have demonstrated the application of our device to detect EGFR from cancer cell lysates and breast cancer serum. Such analysis takes approximately two hours, a relatively fast speed.
